node.title: Millions want mercy for US trucker sentenced to 110 years after killing 4 in horror crash
node.description: An online petition says the crash was a "tragic accident" and his sentence should be reduced.
node.content: ["Millions have signed a petition calling for mercy for a US trucker sentenced to 110 years after killing four people in a horror crash.", "Rogel Lazaro Aguilera-Mederos, 26, was convicted in October this year of four homicide charges and multiple counts of assault and reckless driving after his semi-trailer crashed into stopped traffic in 2019, killing four motorists.", "Prosecutors argued at trial that Aguilera-Mederos knew his brakes were failing but drove past at least one runaway truck ramp as he descended the mountains west of Denver.", "He then recklessly weaved in and out of traffic before his trailer, which was hauling lumber, crashed into stopped traffic and burst into flames, triggering a 28-vehicle pile-up that killed four people and injured six, prosecutors said.", "Aguilera-Mederos told investigators his brakes failed and he tried to avoid hitting other vehicles after losing control. He wept in court as he begged the victims' families for forgiveness and asked the judge for leniency.", "But the Colorado judge last week reluctantly sentenced him to 110 years in prison, saying Colorado law required he impose the mandatory minimum sentences to all the counts Aguilera-Mederos was convicted of.", "Now an online petition calling for Colorado Governor Jared Polis to grant a clemency commutation, which lessens the severity of the sentence, has gained over 4.5 million signatures.", "\"This accident was not intentional, nor was it a criminal act on the drivers part. No one but the trucking company he is/was employed by should be held accountable for this accident,\" the petition states.", "\"Rogel has said several times that he wishes he had the courage to crash and take his own life that day, this tragic accident wasn't done with Intent, it wasn't a criminal act, it was an accident.\"", "Aguilera-Mederos' lawyer James Colgan told KDVR that an application for commutation is \"in the works\".", "\"Part of the application process requires the findings and evaluations by the Department of Corrections be sent to the governor. That isn't the case with Mr Mederos. He hasn't been in the system very long,\" Colgan said.", "In a statement to the NY Times, he added he thought the chances \"pretty good\" that Governor Polis would look at the application favourably.", "\"I have been in this system for 32 years and I have never seen anything like this,\" he said.", "\"This is truly, truly, truly something that is out of the ordinary.\"", "Reuters / Newshub\u00a0"]
